review.title: Identifying Diabetic Patients with High Risk of Readmission
review.abstract: Hospital readmissions are expensive and reflect the inadequacies in healthcare system. In the United States alone, treatment of readmitted diabetic patients exceeds 250 million dollars per year. Early identification of patients facing a high risk of readmission can enable healthcare providers to to conduct additional investigations and possibly prevent future readmissions. This not only improves the quality of care but also reduces the medical expenses on readmission. Machine learning methods have been leveraged on public health data to build a system for identifying diabetic patients facing a high risk of future readmission. Number of inpatient visits, discharge disposition and admission type were identified as strong predictors of readmission. Further, it was found that the number of laboratory tests and discharge disposition together predict whether the patient will be readmitted shortly after being discharged from the hospital (i.e. <30 days) or after a longer period of time (i.e. >30 days). These insights can help healthcare providers to improve inpatient diabetic care. Finally, the cost analysis suggests that \$252.76 million can be saved across 98,053 diabetic patient encounters by incorporating the proposed cost sensitive analysis model.

sections.text: Keywords - Medical Data Analysis, Machine Learning, Collaborative Mining Rule, Feature Importance Mining, Cost-Sensitive Analysis.I. INTRODUCTIONA Survey, conducted by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), found that in 2011, more than 3.3 million patients in the United States were readmitted within 30 days of their discharge. Need for readmission indicates that insufficient care was provided to the patient at the time of initial admission. Inadequate care poses a threat to the lives and treatment of patients leading to higher healthcare costs. Over $41 billion has been spent on treating recurring patients.

sections.text: Numerous previous studies have analyzed the risk factors predicting reuptake rates in diabetics [3], [7], [8], [16], [20], [22], [25] of which important ones have been discussed here. [24] Acute and chronic glycemic control was found to affect reuptake risk in a dataset of more than 29,000 patients over 65 years of age. sections.heading: III. METHODOLOGY
sections.text: A dataset of 101,765 diabetes records collected over a 10-year period (1999-2008) from 130 hospitals in the United States was used for all analyses presented in this paper [22], [25]. Each patient's medical records contained 50 potential risk factors and a label indicating whether the patient was admitted within 30 days, 30 days, or never resumed. Distribution is as follows: 11% of patients were resumed within 30 days, 35% after 30 days, and 54% patients were never resumed. An overview of our methodology is provided in Figure 1. We initially process the data using the methodology described in Section 3.A. From these preprocessed data, we build models to predict resumé rates (Classification, Section 3.B) and identify groups of features that are important for predicting resumé rates (Feature Analysis, Section 3.C), which in turn reveal critical risk factors.

sections.heading: A. Risk Factors
sections.text: Prior to each analysis, we processed the data in the following ways: the primary, secondary and tertiary medical diagnoses were indicated by the ICD9 codes [26]; each ICD9 indicates a unique diagnostic condition; the ICD9 codes recorded more than 1,000 unique values; for many diagnostic conditions (ICD9 codes), data was available for only a few patients; and determining the effect of each of these diagnostic conditions on readmission rates was not feasible. Consequently, we grouped ICD9 codes, which were represented in a total of 10 groups [26]. Grouping was not performed; each of these ICD 9 codes was available in smaller quantities.

sections.heading: C. Feature Analysis
sections.text: The following are two methods of performing the feature analysis to identify critical risk factors.1) Ablation study of risk factors: The importance of individual risk factors can be assessed by conducting an ablation study. An ablation study involves removing one factor after another and comparing the accuracy of predicting risk factors with the accuracy achieved by taking all features into account. Intuitively, removing more important features should lead to a greater decrease in accuracy. Ablation of risk factors was performed to assess the importance of each of these factors. 2) Associative Rule Mining (ARM): In addition to predictive modelling of the main topic, risk factors should be identified and help medical practitioners gain more knowledge.

sections.heading: D. Evaluation Criteria
sections.text: A system for predicting high-risk patients only makes sense if a large proportion of high-risk patients are correctly identified (i.e. high recall) without generating a large number of false alarms (i.e. high precision). Receiver Operating Characteristics (ROC) is omnipresent as one of the best indicators for evaluating classification models, and the research paper [5] clearly demonstrates that there is a deep link between ROC space and Precision Recall (PR) space, so that a curve dominates in the ROC space when it dominates in the PR space.

sections.heading: E. Cost Sensitive Analysis
sections.text: The model must be aligned to maximize the costs that the hospital will save by using the analysis model, which can be done by selecting an appropriate threshold for machine learning algorithms. Let α be the cost per recovery, and β be the cost per Special Diagnosis for patients predicted to be Yes (< 30 or > 30 days of recovery). Let the patient define instances of the test kit based on the cost matrix. Cost matrix is one in which the cost or penalty of classification for each element is specified as in the confusion matrix of special diagnoses. CostMatrix = [TP FN FP TN TN TN TN] (3) Where TP, FN and TN prediction models correspond to true positives, false positives, false negatives and true negatives respectively. sections.heading: IV. RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
sections.text: This section contains the results of caries experiments as described in Section 3. The effectiveness of different classifiers to predict readmission status was discussed in Section 4.A. Section 4.B describes critical risk factors identified by feature analyses using two methods, the ablation study and the Association Rule Mining. Finally, the results of cost-effective analyses are discussed in Section 4.C.

sections.heading: C. Cost Analysis
sections.text: The cost analysis was carried out as explained in Section 3.E. The article [15] states that the cost of resuming diabetes mellitus and its complications at 23,700 resumes is approximately $251 million. Consequently, the cost per resuming α is approximately $10,591 ($250,000, 000 / 23,300). In our research, a specific diagnosis is considered as an additional admission day on which the physician can perform another diagnosis that could lead to the discovery of new complications in the patient. Therefore, the cost of a specific diagnosis is considered as the cost per day of admission to the hospital. Our data set indicates that the average time in hospital for diabetic patients is 4,396 days. Therefore, the cost of a day admission is considered $2,409 ($10,591 / 4,396).
